displayed_text: Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything. Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill?

Healthcare Professional: He’s having some back pain. Doctor: Right. Family Member: We’re just kind of… Doctor: Show me where. (paper shuffling) Family Member: Yeah that’s what we wanted, that’s what we did. We just did it though. Doctor: Right here? Yeah I know that’s why it’s not. Does this hurt when I push? Patient: Not – a little bit. Doctor: A little bit. Not too bad though. Patient: No. Doctor: Is there anything that brings on the pain? Family Member: Let me tell you, I think sometimes J___ over exerts himself. Patient: I might if I have…

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway. Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in.

Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow.

Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner. Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation. Um uh, so one standard of care would be radiation alone; the second standard of care would be radiation plus hormone therapy generally for two years, which sucks, quite frankly.

Patient: Okay. I wanna discuss with Dr. L___ who is my oncolgoist said I should really Doctor: I communicate with her, etcetera notes, translated to him real time so to speak. Patient: Okay. I understand that you’re Doctor: see in the notes Patient: Um I did a couple of months ago. Yeah because I did something PSA… Doctor: Okay. And did you plans in the future? Patient: It’s open-ended . I wanted Doctor: There might come a time that we might do something perfectly capable… and at that point Patient: Okay. Perfect. Fine. Doctor: Alrighty. Take this with you. It’s the consent form. The next step on my part would be to contact the study team. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Either he or his scheduling staff. And we’ll be in touch with you by telephone.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right.

Patient: Well, that’s that the uh, ointment. Doctor: And did you see any of your blood tests and lab results? Patient: I did. Doctor: Your, uh, white count, uh, was okay. You’re less anemic than you have been, so did you get a blood transfusion or anything? Patient: No. (laughter) Doctor: Are you drinking enough fluid? You’re not dehydrated and concentrated yourself up? Patient: No. Doctor: That’s good. Um. Platelets are normal. (pause) Patient: Mmmm. I didn’t see that. (pause) Doctor: Six five oh, yeah, two months ago. So, you said you did read the scans or? Patient: Well, I saw them, you know, in the lab works screen. I didn’t, I didn’t look at the —- I mean, I couldn’t see the bone scans or anything like that. They don’t post those. Now, the PSA wasn’t posted when I looked at it, uh, this morning. Doctor: Umm, (pause) Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I get, you know, I think in the trials that they did with these drugs, and these are now not even new anymore They’re sort of old now. We’ve been doing this a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, they did trials in men before chemotherapy and after chemotherapy. It’s kind of the dividing line. And in both cases, they saw that the men responded very well, and that it improved survival of the men. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. Uh, another third of the guys, the PSA drops really nicely, and then starts to go back up usually six months or so, and then the third group of guys, usually the PSA is a readout. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease-

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home. Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and-

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s a reasonable ---- Family Member: But it wouldn’t stay down if things weren’t okay --- if you were getting worse, either. I mean, is there a false – Doctor: I mean, occasionally we have a patient where all the disease is getting better, and then one spot starts to grow. That’s where, that would be the one place we kind of fall through the cracks. But, usually, - the PSA represents the sum of all of the cancers in your body are contributing to it. So, usually, when it’s going down, we sort of think that the sum is going down. And, when it’s going up, we think that it’s starting to be resistant. Um. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: But it’s an indication of prostate cancer, and as far as we know, that’s all that he has. Doctor: Right. Right. Family Member: Even though, it’s in different places. Doctor: Right. And, sometimes when the PSA goes up, the scans can still look stable, because they’re not as sensitive to changes as the, as the – Patient: As the chemical – Doctor: Blood count. Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Very. His name is D_, too. Doctor: Oh, okay. Well ---- Patient: He’s named for my son, I’m sure. She likes him a lot better than me. Family Member: That’s not clear. That’s – Doctor: Well, it looks like the PSA came down again. Patient: It came down a little bit. Doctor: Down to one point five. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. The, uh, the other thing that came back was your DNA test. Patient: The genetics. Doctor: Yeah, did you see that or not? Patient: No! I didn’t get a copy that I’m aware of. Uh, did you get it? Doctor: Yeah. So, it actually looks like, uh, (coughs)

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Because it’s – Doctor: It’s connected! Patient: Connected, and then it’ll still be goin’ in the pad, and if it go – Doctor: So, I’m sayin’ – Patient: In that pad in that area. Doctor: I know you. I would rather that you know there’s a potential of two bags. Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God. Patient: No but I mean it just I just didn’t drink enough water Doctor: Oh my gosh. Patient: so I drunk so some more water, still I did so I took the other one and I put it in there then when oh God, I said… Doctor: Otherwise you have to crush it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You could crush it – and-

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, lovastatin forty milligrams a day Patient: Mm, hmm Doctor: The probiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Your calcium with vitamin D one a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Cranberry extract, uh, twice a day. Patient: Uh, once a day; I dropped it back to once. Doctor: And the B12 once a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your Xgeva every month?
